comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Probably William Gorham Rice Jr. (1892-1979). A few years after this was taken, WGR Jr. was in WWI as a Red Cross ambulance driver. He was awarded the Croix de Guerre in 1917 for exceptional courage. He became a law professor at the University of Wisconsin. His father William Gorham Rice (1856-1945), ran for Mayor of Albany (1903), ran for Lt. Governor of New York (1914), served as Civil Service Commissioner (appt. 1919). Was also a world-renowned authority on carillons, apparently. His papers are in the New York State Library: www.nysl.nysed.gov/msscfa/sc12866.htm

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: This might be William Gorham Rice (1856-1945) who, in 1915, became a member of the New York State Civil Service Commission. Brief biography here. A noted supporter of Civil Service reform, he had earlier been a member of the United States Civil Service Commission, from 1895 to 1898. I can't find any photos of William Gorham Rice (or his namesake son, born 1892) on the Internet, though, so I can't compare- but this guy sure looks like a civil servant. Edit: Oops. Penny posted while I was digging around the Internet. I can't tell of this photo depicts a youthful guy in his fifties, or an unusually mature-looking guy in his twenties (assuming the photo dates from the early-mid 1910s.) I notice that he sports a pinkie ring and no wedding ring, though, so maybe William Jr. is the more likely candidate.
